member.summary: The parser shifts a terminal onto the stack.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Debugging.ParseActionType.GoTo
member.summary: The parser transitions to a different state without modifying the stack.

member.summary: The parser halts and signifies a successful parse.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Debugging.ParseActionType.Ambiguous
member.summary: Multiple actions are defined for the transition symbol.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType
member.summary: Constants which describe the rules which are enforced by a parser to determine whether input is syntactically valid.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.None
member.summary: Used for variable declaration.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Terminal
member.summary: Placeholder for a TerminalSymbol. A Terminal rule cannot have sub-rules; attempting to add a sub-rule to a terminal rule will cause an exception to be thrown. A terminal rule is analogous to a leaf node on a syntax tree.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.NonTerminal
member.summary: Placeholder for a NonTerminalSymbol.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Alternation
member.summary: A logical 'OR' is applied between each of the sub-rules. Example: (A | B); the rule succeeds if either 'A' or 'B' succeeds.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Concatenation
member.summary: Each sub-rule must succeed, and is expected to be appear in sequential order. Example: (A, B); the rule succeeds for "AB", but not for "ACB"

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Conjunction
member.summary: Currently not supported.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Optional
member.summary: The rule may or may not succeed. If a sub-rule fails, the optional rule still succeeds. Example: A, [B]; the rule requires A to succeed, but B may or may not succeed

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Repetition
member.summary: Each of the sub-rules may succeed zero or more times.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Negation
member.summary: Currently not supported.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison
member.summary: Constants which determine the manner in which a terminal symbol's value is compared to values in the compilation source.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.Literal
member.summary: The value associated with the symbol is a literal string. The syntax parser will compare values in the compilation target with the associated value and generate an error if the values do not match exactly. The comparison under this setting is case-sensitive.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.LiteralIgnoreCase
member.summary: Same as the 'Literal' setting, except that character casing is ignored for the string comparisons.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.RegularExpression
member.summary: The value associated with the symbol is implied to be a regular expression pattern. The System._Text.RegularExpressions.Regex class is used to determine whether values in the compilation target match the pattern assigned to the terminal symbol's value.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement
member.summary: Constants which describe the language element of tokens produced by the associated TerminalSymbol.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Undefined
member.summary: No language element is specified.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Comment
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol are not semantically significant to the associated grammar.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.NewLine
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent newlines. Note that a terminal symbol with this value always the regular expression pattern defined by the NewLineSymbol to tokenize content.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Whitespace
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent whitespace characters such as the space character or tab character. This value is used by the WhitespaceSymbol, but can be used by any terminal symbol; tokens generated by such symbols are considered to be semantically insignificant to the associated grammar.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.ReservedKeyword
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent reserved keywords.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.ContextSensitiveKeyword
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent context-sensitive keywords, i.e., can be either a keyword or identifier depending on the usage.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Identifier
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent identifiers.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.StringLiteral
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent a string or character literal.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.NumericLiteral
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent a numeric literal.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.DateLiteral
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent a date/time literal.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Operator
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent mathematical, relational, or logical operators, such as +, -, >, |, etc.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Punctuation
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent punctuation symbols such as a semicolon, parentheses, braces, etc.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.PreprocessorDirective
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent preprocessor directives, i.e., '#region', '#if', '#else', '#endif', etc.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.PreprocessorDirectiveText
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent text within a preprocessor directive.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.LineContinuation
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent the continuation of a logical line. They will cause an immediately following LineTerminator token to be skipped.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.Unrecognized
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent unrecognized content.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.DocCommentStart
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent the beginning of an XML documentation comment line.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.DocCommentText
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent the text within an XML documentation comment.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.DocCommentTag
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent the tags within an XML documentation comment.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.LineTerminator
member.summary: Tokens produced by this terminal symbol represent the end marker for a logical line unless they are immediately preceded by a LineContinuation token.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement.EndOfStream

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxTreePruningMode
member.summary: Constants which describe whether a non-terminal syntax node appears in the syntax tree produced when a document is parsed.

remarks.p: The term "pruning" refers to the process of removing non-terminal syntax nodes which, for whatever reason, are not considered important to the consumer of the syntax tree. This process provides a simple mechanism by which to convert a concrete syntax tree (CST) to an abstract syntax tree (AST).
Terminal nodes are never removed from a syntax tree, since they always represent significant content.
Significant child nodes of non-terminal nodes which are pruned become immediate children of the first ancestor node that is not pruned.

By default, non-terminal nodes which have only one child, where that child is itself a non-terminal node, do not appear in the syntax tree. Non-terminal nodes whose name is prefixed with an underscore ('_') also do not appear. This is the equivalent of combining the 'BasedOnChildren' and 'BasedOnName' constants.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxTreePruningMode.None
member.summary: All non-terminal nodes appear in the tree.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxTreePruningMode.BasedOnChildren
member.summary: Non-terminal syntax nodes which have only one child, where that child is itself a non-terminal syntax node, are not included in the syntax tree.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxTreePruningMode.BasedOnName
member.summary: Non-terminal syntax nodes which are associated with a NonTerminalSymbol whose name begins with an underscore ('_') are considered to be used internally for the purpose of parsing, and do not appear in the syntax tree.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxTreePruningMode.Custom
member.summary: The IncludeInSyntaxTree method is called, allowing a language-specific implementation to make the determination as to whether a node appears in the syntax tree.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar
member.summary: Encapsulates a formal, context-free grammar whose production rules are used to parse and validate textual input.

remarks.p: The syntax of a programming language is defined by its grammar. This formal definition provides a way to define what constitutes a legal sequence of characters in a concise, unambiguous manner.

A syntax analyzer is a finite state machine which evaluates textual input according to the rules defined within the grammar, determining whether the input conforms to these rules. The starting point for syntax analysis is exposed through the StartSymbol property. Syntax analysis is realized by recursively iterating the start symbol's Rules collection.
The main components of a grammar definition are encapsulated by the TerminalSymbol and NonTerminalSymbol classes.

A TerminalSymbol represents the string or pattern which must be matched in order for the corresonding rule to be satisfied. For example, a TerminalSymbol for the string "Foo" would evaluate the input string and signify success if it begins with "Foo", and signify failure if it does not. More complex evaluations are made possible through the use of regular expression patterns, which the TerminalSymbol class also supports. A TerminalSymbol also has no child rules, which reflects the meaning of its key - it represents the terminal point of a syntax rule evaluation.

A NonTerminalSymbol represents a grouping of rules which usually consists of multiple TerminalSymbols and other NonTerminalSymbols. A NonTerminalSymbol can be thought of as a shortcut through which a rule path can appear in different locations within the grammar without having to duplicate the logic. Unlike the TerminalSymbol, the NonTerminalSymbol class exposes a Rules collection; the contents of this collection defines the order in which the grammatical rules are evaluated.
A syntax rule is a representation of a production rule of the grammar. Each type of rule represents a logical "operator" which defines the context for the evaluations performed by the TerminalSymbol.

Syntax analysis during a parsing operation that analyzes each syntax rule defined for the grammar by recursively iterating the start symbol's Rules collection, analyzing the token stream produced during the lexical analysis phase. The Parse method returns an instance of the SyntaxTree class, which provides an abstraction of the input that was parsed. A SyntaxTree is then used by consumers for semantic interpretation of the input.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.StartSymbol
member.summary: Returns or sets a reference to the NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for a parsing operation.

remarks.p: When parsing starts, each production rule of the grammar is analyzed until all the input text is consumed, or until all rules have been evaluated. The StartSymbol defines the starting point for this analysis.
The StartSymbol property must be set to a non-null value prior to beginning a parsing operation, or an exception is thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.TerminalSymbols
member.summary: Returns a read-only collection which contains all TerminalSymbol instances defined for this grammar.

remarks.p: Terminal symbols are literal characters that can appear in the inputs to or outputs from the production rules of a formal grammar and are irreducible, i.e., cannot be broken down into "smaller" units.
TerminalSymbols are added to this collection automatically upon creation. Create new TerminalSymbol instances using the static Create method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.NonTerminalSymbols
member.summary: Returns a collection of the non-terminal symbols which define this grammar.

remarks.p: A NonTerminalSymbol is a symbol of the grammar which can be replaced by some combination of terminal and non-terminal symbols.
A NonTerminalSymbol exposes a Rules collection to which syntax rules are added, thus defining the syntax for the grammar.
The StartSymbol property references a NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for parse operations.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespacePattern
member.summary: Returns or sets the regular expression pattern used to identify whitespace by the syntax analysis layer.

remarks.p: By default, the pattern '[ \t]+' is used, which matches the ASCII characters 9 (horizontal tab) and 32 (space). This property can be set to any valid regular expression pattern to change the definition of whitespace for this grammar.
To suppress automatic whitespace parsing, set this property to null or an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespaceSymbol
member.summary: Returns a TerminalSymbol based on the value of the WhitespacePattern property, which can be used to match whitespace characters.

remarks.p: Use the WhitespaceSymbolName property to assign a name to the symbol, which can then be used to refer to the whitespace symbol from within grammar definition scripts and by the indexer of the TerminalSymbols collection.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespaceSymbolName
member.summary: Returns or sets the name that is used to reference the WhitespaceSymbol

remarks.p: This value can be used to obtain a reference to the WhitespaceSymbol from the TerminalSymbols collection's indexer, although the collection does not actually contain this symbol.
This value can also be used within grammar definition scripts to denote a TerminalRule which expects whitespace.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageBase.GetErrorAlias(Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Symbol)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, returns a customized error alias which is used to represent the specified grammar symbol when the parser expects to find that symbol and does not.
member.param: The terminal or non-terminal symbol for which an error message is to be returned.

remarks.p: For non-terminal symbols, the base class implementation returns the name of the symbol. For terminal symbols, the symbol's Value is displayed when the Comparison property returns 'Literal' or 'LiteralIgnoreCase'. For the case where the Comparison property returns 'RegularExpression', the string representation of the LanguageElement property is displayed, unless it returns 'Undefined', in which case the symbol's name is returned. This value is then formatted with the word 'expected', and displayed to the user.

remarks.p: When a lexer state has been entered, and a newline is encountered before the symbol which exits that lexer state, the token which is expected to exit that lexer state is then known to be missing. In this case, a LexerToken is created for that exit symbol, with a zero length, and returned from the GetNextToken method. Such tokens are considered to be missing.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol
member.summary: A grammar symbol which is composed of some combination of terminal and nonterminal symbols; also known as a syntactic variable.

remarks.p: A non-terminal symbol is basically a container for production rules and terminal symbols. The rule tree defined by a non-terminal symbol can be placed at multiple locations within the rule tree, providing a mechanism by which to avoid duplication of logic.

Consider the C# programming language concept of identifiers. Syntactic rules apply to what constitutes a valid identifier - it must begin with either an alphabetic character or underscore, followed by the same or one or more integers, and not be a keyword. In order to define a production rule that unambiguously identifies such strings, several criteria are necessary; the resulting rule tree looks something like this: Identifier -> Concatenation -> Matches regex pattern "^[a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*" -> NotAKeyword -> Negation -> Alternation -> "using" -> "namespace" -> "class" -> "public|private|protected|internal" -> ... As evidenced by the above example, a fairly extensive rule hierarchy is necessary to express even something as simple as an identifier. Considering that a full definition for the C# programming language requires checks for an identifier in dozens or perhaps hundreds of places within the rule tree, the benefit of providing a means by which a "shortcut" form of expression can be used is evident.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.Grammar
member.summary: Returns a reference to the associated Grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.Rules
member.summary: Returns a collection of SyntaxRule instances which describe the syntax rules for this NonTerminalSymbol.

remarks.p: The syntax for a grammar is defined by its production rules; the production rules for a grammar are exposed via the Rules collection of the grammar's StartSymbol.

The grammar's StartSymbol property references a NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for parse operations. The order in which these rules are evaluated is determined by the contents of this collection. Each rule therein is analyzed by recursively analyzing descendant rules until a TerminalRule is encountered. A TerminalRule has no rules of its own; its purpose is to perform the actual parsing to determine whether the current input is valid.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRulesCollection.AddTerminalRule(Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol)
member.summary: Adds a new SyntaxRule to this collection with a RuleType of 'Terminal'.
member.param: The TerminalSymbol associated with the rule.
member.returns: The created SyntaxRule.

remarks.p: A terminal rule represents the endpoint of a production rule. The terminal rule attempts to parse the input and if the attempt is successful, the matching characters are consumed and parsing continues. If the attempt fails, the parent rule is notified and determines whether an error is logged.
A terminal rule cannot have sub-rules; attempting to add members to the Rules collection of a SyntaxRule whose RuleType returns 'Terminal' results in an exception being thrown.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.AlternationRule
member.summary: Class which encapsulates the behavior of the Alternation syntax rule.

remarks.p: An AlternationRule is used to ensure that one of a group of tokens appear at the current position in the input stream. For example, an AlternationRule with three TerminalRules, 'A', 'B', and 'C', in its Rules collection, expects the input stream to contain any one of those three characters. If any one of the characters are present, the AlternationRule succeeds.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.AlternationRule.RuleType
member.summary: Returns the SyntaxRuleType constant associated with this class ('Alternation').

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.ConcatenationRule
member.summary: Class which encapsulates the behavior of the Concatenation syntax rule.

remarks.p: A ConjunctionRule is used to ensure that tokens appear in sequential order. For example, a ConjunctionRule with three TerminalRules, 'A', 'B', and 'C', in its Rules collection, expects the input stream to contain those three characters, and expects them to appear in that order. If any character is missing, or present but not in the required order, the ConjunctionRule fails.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.ConcatenationRule.RuleType
member.summary: Returns the SyntaxRuleType constant associated with this class ('Concatenation').

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.OptionalRule
member.summary: Class which encapsulates the behavior of the Optional syntax rule.

remarks.p: An OptionalRule is the equivalent of a RepetitionRule whose MinimumOccurrences property is set to zero, and whose MaximumOccurrences property is set to one.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.RepetitionRuleBase
member.summary: Base class for the RepetitionRule and OptionalRule classes.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.RepetitionRuleBase.RuleType
member.summary: Returns the SyntaxRuleType constant associated with this class.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.RepetitionRuleBase.IsOptional
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this rule must succeed at least one time in order for the rule to be satisfied.

remarks.p: This property always returns true for optional rules.
For repetition rules, this property returns true if the value of the MinimumOccurrences property is equal to zero, and false otherwise.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.OptionalRule.RuleType
member.summary: Returns the SyntaxRuleType constant associated with this class ('Optional').

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.ConjunctionRule
member.summary: Class which encapsulates the behavior of the Conjunction syntax rule.

remarks.p: Note that the parser used by the TextDocument class does not support the conjunction rule. The rule exists to support custom parser implementations.

Note that rule conjunction can be expressed using regular expression patterns, by setting the terminal symbol's Comparison property to 'RegularExpression', and assigning the appropriate pattern to the Value property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.ConjunctionRule.RuleType
member.summary: Returns the SyntaxRuleType constant associated with this class ('Conjunction').

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.RepetitionRule
member.summary: Class which encapsulates the behavior of the Repetition syntax rule.

remarks.p: Note that the parser used by the TextDocument class only supports the 'zero or more' expressions of the repetition rule. As such, RepetitionRule supports only zero or more expressions.

A RepetitionRule requires its sub-rules to succeed at least the number of times indicated by the value of the MinimumOccurrences property. Each sub-rule is evaluated the number of times indicated by the value of the MaximumOccurrences property. If MaximumOccurrences returns null, the rule can succed any number of times.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol
member.summary: An irreducible element of the associated Grammar which can appear in the inputs to or outputs from the production rules of the grammar.

remarks.p: A terminal symbol can be a literal string or a regular expression. This literal string or regular expression is compared to strings in the text being analyzed by the syntax analysis layer when determining whether a statement is valid in the context of the associated grammar.

A terminal symbol represents the terminal point for a production rule. Production rules such as Concatenation, Alternation, SyntacticFactor, etc. can be likened to logical tokens, whereas a terminal symbol does the actual character matching. All production rules must produce a rule tree which contains at least one TerminalRule as a leaf node, or an exception is thrown during the parsing operation.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.DefaultBoundaryPattern
member.summary: Returns the regular expression pattern used by default for the BoundaryPattern property ('\W').

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol._IsSignificant(Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.LanguageElement)
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether tokens generated by terminal symbols with the specified represent significant content.
member.param: The LanguageElement to test.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.ToString
member.summary: Returns the string representation of this object.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsExplicitlyNamed
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether a value is explicitly assigned to the Name property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.BoundaryPattern
member.summary: Returns or sets the regular expression pattern which defines the character or characters expected to follow tokens parsed by this TerminalSymbol.

remarks.p: Boundary checking can be suppressed altogether by setting this property to an empty string. In this case, tokens parsed by this terminal symbol do not check the character or characters which follow the parsed token.

In the absence of an explicit setting, the regular expression pattern '\W' (non-alphanumeric characters) is used for terminal symbols whose LanguageElement property is set to 'ReservedKeyword', 'ContextSensitiveKeyword', or 'Identifier'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.BoundaryPatternResolved
member.summary: Returns the resolved value of the BoundaryPattern property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Grammar
member.summary: Returns a reference to the associated Grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Value
member.summary: Returns the value associated with this terminal symbol.

remarks.p: When a string is compiled against the associated Grammar, this value is used to compare values in the string being compiled. The manner in which the values are compared is determined by the value of the Comparison property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Comparison
member.summary: Returns a value which determines the manner in which values in the string being compiled are compared against this terminal symbol.

remarks.p: Terminal symbols support three types of character matching: literal, both with and without regard to character casing, and regular expression.

For example, to create a terminal symbol which matches text containing only alphabetic characters, set the Comparison property to 'RegularExpression', and assign the value '[a-zA-Z]*' to the Value property.

Note that in cases where the 'RegularExpression' setting is used, it is recommended that a value be assigned to the Lookahead property when possible. If the regular expression pattern begins with a literal string of characters, assigning this string to the Lookahead property will enable the lexical anyalysis layer to inexpensively determine whether the pattern should be evaluated based on the lookahead.

For example, consider a simplified pattern for pre-processor directives, '#(if|elif|endif|else)'. Because matches yielded by this pattern must begin with a '#', assigning this value to the Lookahead property enables the lexical analysis layer to bypass pattern evaluation in cases where the input string cannot possibly match the pattern, i.e., when the next character in the input stream is not a '#'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Lookahead
member.summary: Returns or sets a string which defines the character or characters which must appear at the beginning of the input stream in order for this symbol to parse successfully.

remarks.p: This property is only applicable for terminal symbols whose Comparison property is set to 'RegularExpression', since unambiguous lookahead criteria is already defined for literal string matching. In cases where the pattern to be matched always begins with the same character or characters, this property can be used to provide a hint to the lexer, so that this terminal symbol is only evaluated in cases where the next character(s) in the input stream match the value of this property. This can improve performance by reducing the number of string comparisons during the scanning/lexing phase.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.LanguageElement
member.summary: Returns or sets a constant which defines the language element for tokens generated by this symbol.

remarks.p: The LanguageElement property cannot be set to 'EndOfStream' or 'NewLine', as these values are reserved for the terminal symbol returned from the EndOfStreamSymbol and NewLineSymbol properties, respectively. Attempting to assign either of these values to this property will cause an exception to be thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsSignificant
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether tokens generated by this terminal symbol represent significant content.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsNewLine
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this terminal symbol represents a newline.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsWhitespace
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this terminal symbol represents whitespace.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsEndOfStream
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this terminal symbol represents an end of stream marker.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.ConsumesText
member.summary: Returns or sets a boolean value which indicates whether tokens produced by the lexer for this symbol have length.

remarks.p: The ConsumesText property makes it possible to use the Value property strictly to define matching criteria, while preventing the lexer from consuming the text that it matches. For example, to support languages which consider newlines to be significant content, a terminal symbol could be created with a regex pattern for newlines, and a value of false for ConsumesText. During the lexical analysis phase, text that meets the criteria defined for the symbol would be matched as usual, but the token produced would have zero length, and the input stream left unaffected.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason
member.summary: Constants which describe the reason for an import error.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.None
member.summary: Used for variable initialization.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.EmptyGrammarDefinition
member.summary: The grammar definition is empty.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingDeclaration
member.summary: The left-hand side of the statement cannot be parsed into a valid identifier. All statements must begin with a valid identifier which is not enclosed in quotes; this value may represent the name of a TerminalSymbol or NonTerminalSymbol

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.DuplicateIdentifier
member.summary: The left-hand side of the statement contains an identifier which has already been used.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.UnrecognizedContent
member.summary: The right-hand side of the statement contains content which is not recognizable under the current grammar notation.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingAssignmentSymbol
member.summary: The statement does not contain an AssignmentSymbol (typically an equals sign) following the declaration. All statements must contain one and only one assignment symbol following the declaration.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingEndOfStatement
member.summary: The statement does not contain an EndOfStatementSymbol (typically a semicolon).

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.DuplicateAssignmentSymbol
member.summary: The statement contains more than one AssignmentSymbol. All statements must contain one and only one assignment symbol following the declaration.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingOperator
member.summary: An operator is expected at the specified location. This is usually caused by the occurrence of two adjacent operands.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingOperand
member.summary: An operand is expected at the specified location. This is usually caused by the occurrence of two adjacent operators.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.GroupingSymbolMismatch
member.summary: An grouping symbol, such as a GroupingBlockOpeningSymbol or GroupingBlockClosingSymbol was encountered without a corresponding opening/closing symbol.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.InvalidTerminalDeclaration
member.summary: The terminal symbol declaration could not be parsed into a valid statement.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.InvalidAssignment
member.summary: The left-hand side of the statement contains content that is not valid for an assignment.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.UndeclaredReference
member.summary: A reference to an identifier that was never declared was encountered.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.InvalidDeclaration
member.summary: More than one identifier was encountered on the left-hand side of a statement.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.InvalidRegularExpression
member.summary: A terminal symbol was designated as a regular expression pattern, but the pattern specified was not valid.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingValue
member.summary: An XML tag has no value specified.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.MissingName
member.summary: A declaration is missing a value for the 'Name' property.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParseErrorReason.InvalidConjunctionRuleDescendant

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParser.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses the specified string.
member.param: The EBNF content to be loaded.
member.returns: An EbnfParseResult instance which describes the result of the parse operation.

remarks.p: If successful, the returned EbnfParseResult object's Success property returns true, and the Grammar property returns the resulting Grammar.
If unsuccessful, the returned EbnfParseResult object's Errors property returns the errors encountered, and the Grammar property returns null.

The character encoding.

remarks.p: If successful, the returned EbnfParseResult object's Success property returns true, and the Grammar property returns the resulting Grammar.
If unsuccessful, the returned EbnfParseResult object's Errors property returns the errors encountered, and the Grammar property returns null.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParser.NewLine
member.summary: Returns or sets the character string which is used to represent new lines.

remarks.p: In the case where the NewLine property is not explicitly set, the input string is searched for the presence of typical newline character sequences, i.e., '\r\n' and '\n'. Upon detection of the first newline, the value is cached and assumed to be the line delimiting character. This behavior can be overriden by explicitly setting the NewLine property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParser.Tokens
member.summary: Returns an enumerator containing the StatementToken instances which comprise the set of all strings found within the associated script.

remarks.p: This enumerator contains tokens for all parsed strings, appearing in the same order in which they appear in the string passed to the Parse method. It can be used to format the script.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.EbnfParserNotation
member.summary: Encapsulates the properties of the notation used to represent an EBNF (Extended Backus-Naur Form) grammar definition.

remarks.p: The Ebnf notation is used to define the string values which identify reserved symbols within the grammar, for example, the assignment operator or end-of-statement marker.

By default, the EbnfParser class expects input that conforms to the Extended Backup-Naur Form definition, as standardized in 1996 by the ISO/IEC 14977 specification (visit the Internation Organization for Standardization website for details).

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement
member.summary: Encapsulates a production rule statement as parsed from a grammar definition script.

remarks.p: When a grammar definition script is parsed, each occurrence of the EndOfStatementSymbol marks the end of a grammar statement; a GrammarStatement instance is created for the content preceding that marker.
The resulting GrammarStatement is then tokenized, using the symbols as defined by the associated EbnfParserNotation. Each successfully parsed token appears as a member of the Tokens collection.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.ToString
member.summary: Returns the string representation of this object.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.GetLine(Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.StatementToken)
member.summary: Returns a string containing the line on which the specified token appears.
member.param: The token to test.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.GetLine(Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.StatementToken,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns a string containing the line on which the specified token appears.
member.param: The token to test.
[out] Upon return, contains the character position at which the line begins.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.Text
member.summary: Returns the string value which was parsed from the script to create this statement.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.CharacterPosition
member.summary: Returns the position of the first character of this statement, as relative to the first character in the associated script.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.TokenList
member.summary: Returns a list of the tokens which comprise this statement, in hierarchical form.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.FlatList
member.summary: Returns a flat list of the tokens which comprise this statement.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.Tokens
member.summary: Returns a read-only collection containing the StatementToken instances of which this statement is comprised.

remarks.p: The collection returned from this property contains a token for each parsed symbol, in the same order in which they appear in the imported script. Iterating this list and concatenating the value of each member's Text property will reconstruct the original string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.Symbol
member.summary: Returns the symbol whose declaration this statement represents, or null if the statement does not represent a declaration.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.GrammarStatement.Declaration
member.summary: Returns the SymbolToken which represents this statement's declaration, or null if the statement does not represent a declaration.

member.summary: Returns the one-based line number at which this token appears, as relative to the first character in the input text.

remarks.p: Line number are determined by counting the number of newlines that precede the token, with the newline character(s) being defined by the value of the grammar's NewLine property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Ebnf.StatementToken.IsSignificant
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this token represents significant content.

This property returns false for the following classes:
WhitespaceToken SpecialSequence CommentBlock
All other derived classes return true.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.IServiceLocator
member.summary: Defines a interface for an object that provides support for registering, unregistering and locating instances of objects that provide specific services.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.IServiceLocator.RegisterService(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Registers a core service of type 'serviceType'.

remarks.para: Only one instance of a core service type can be registered. Core service types are used to provide essential services. To register a non-core service type use the RegisterService overload that takes a string key.

member.param: The core service Type to register.
The core service instance to register.

member.name: M:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.IServiceLocator.RegisterService(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Registers a non-core service with a unique string key.

remarks.para: Each non-core service must be registered with a unique string key. There are no requirements on the format of the key.

member.param: The unique string key of the non-core service Type to register.
The non-core service instance to register.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.PointTrackingMode
member.summary: Determines how s track between snapshots.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.PointTrackingMode.Positive
member.summary: The point tracks toward the end of the document. An insertion at the current position pushes the point to the end of the inserted text. If a replacement contains the point, it will end up at the end of the replacement text.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.PointTrackingMode.Negative
member.summary: The point tracks toward the beginning of the document. An insertion at the current position leaves the point unchanged. If a replacement contains the point, it will end up at the beginning of the replacement text.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.SpanTrackingMode
member.summary: Determines how s track between snapshots.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeExclusive
member.summary: The leading edge uses a positive tracking mode and the trailing edge uses a neagtive tracking mode. This causes the span to not expand when text is inserted at either boundary.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeInclusive
member.summary: The leading edge uses a negative tracking mode and the trailing edge uses a positive tracking mode. This causes the span to expand when text is inserted at either boundary.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.SpanTrackingMode.EdgePositive
member.summary: Both edges of the span use a positive tracking mode.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeNegative
member.summary: Both edges of the span use a negative tracking mode.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.TabEntryBehavior
member.summary: Determines what gets inserted into a when a tab key is entered.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.TabEntryBehavior.KeepTabs
member.summary: When a tab character is entered it is inserted into the document 'as is' (i.e. as a tab character).

member.name: F:Infragistics.Documents.TabEntryBehavior.ReplaceTabsWithSpaces
member.summary: When a tab character is entered it is converted to an appropriate number of spaces in the document based upon the TextDocument.TabExtent setting.

member.summary: Removes all the Undo and Redo history that relates to this TextDocument.

remarks.para: Note: this is equivalent to calling the 's RemoveAll method with a filter that removes only undo units whose Target is this TextDocument. member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.TextDocumentSnapshotScanner
member.summary: Exposes methods for scanning through a snapshot of a

remarks.para: This class targets a specific instance of a snapshot and is created via the snapshots CreateScanner method. It is used for efficiently scanning thru the snapshots lines, tokens and words.

The property is used to scan thru the snapshot. It can either be set explicitly (it defaults to zero) or via the , , , or methods. Once set, the , , and read-only properties can be used to query what is at the CurrentOffset. In addition, there are 'Peek' next/previous token and word methods to look ahead or behind without changing the CurrentOffset.

Note: even though the snapshot that it targets is thread-safe, the scanner is not. Therefore it should be created on the same thread that it is used on (i.e. each thread accessing a scanner should create its own). Trying to access the properties and methods of a scanner created on another thread will raise an InvalidOperationException.
